taxonomy.title: Office of the Historian Subject Taxonomy of the History of U.S. Foreign Relations
taxonomy.subtitle: Collection: Genres/Forms

description.p:
The Subject Taxonomy of the History of U.S. Foreign Relations is a hierarchical taxonomy that consists of categories and tags. The taxonomy is organized into nine (9) top-level categories:
Agreements and Mandates
Events
Genres/Forms
Organizations
People
Places
Presidential Administrations
Secretarial Tenures
Topics Below these top-level categories are additional nested levels of categories and tags, becoming more specific at deeper levels.

collection.label: Genres/Forms
collection.definition: Terms that describe what a historic document or other resource *is* rather than what the resource is about.

concept.definition: Visual and informational works, including but not limited to charts, diagrams, illustrations, infographics, photographs, maps, and tables.

concept.example: “The CIA's Directorate of Analysis produces a number of intelligence products in support of customers in the US government.”

concept.definition: The President's Daily Brief (PDB) is a daily summary of high-level, all-source intelligence information and analysis produced for the President of the United States. Targeted at the key national security issues and concerns of the President, the PDB is distributed only to the President, Vice President, and a select group of Cabinet-level officials designated by the President. The PDB is coordinated and delivered by the Office of the Director of National Intelligence (ODNI) with contributions from the Central Intelligence Agency and other U.S. Intelligence Community elements.
concept.historyNote: The PDB has been presented, in some form, to the United States President since 1946. In 2014, the PDB transitioned from a print product to electronic delivery at the request of then-President Barack Obama.

concept.definition: Documents representing the arguments of one or more parties and other documents submitted to, or generated by, a court in a particular case.

Contemporanous documentation of a conversation in the form of a written memorandum. Used regularly in the United States government, memoranda of conversation often include the date and time of the meeting, location, and participants as well as notes and transcribed portions of conversations.

Specific form of Executive Order that states Presidential guidance on United States foreign policy, military policy, and other national security matters. Issued by the President with the advice and consent of the National Security Council, national security directives state requirements for the executive branch carry the force and effect of law.
concept.historyNote: Since the founding of President Hary Truman's National Security Council in 1947, every United States President has issued national security directives. Each Presidential Administration chooses its own nomenclature for these directives.
